The question being debated has never been “do masks work?”

Even the righteous contrarians pursing "normalcy" do not question  masks, but critique whether some masks are such low-quality they are ineffective, or an imagined risk/benefit equation of certain mask policies.
🧵/11

So, these mask-wearing trials at UM have zero to show with respect to whether masks “work”, and tell us mostly about what sort of mask-wearing policies are likely to be effective.

These trials in this WHO review are hardly the entire scope of mask-wearing research, however.
🧵/8

This is effectively the same limitation of the JAMA N95 vs. surgical mask trial.

When the intervention is only in applied in a narrow circumstance, yet the community transmission is pervasive, there’s little chance the trial design is valid.
https://t.co/vnzUX1Grhz
🧵/7

The follow-up study in 2012 was much larger, but the same limitations.  An even smaller proportion of students were randomized, and a grand total of 5 hours of mask-wearing occurred per day – ample time for contamination in the other waking hours.
🧵/6 https://t.co/iWj6Y8zqo5

Two larger studies were residence hall studies at the University of Michigan. It is immediately obvious why these are both relevant and not relevant.

The most important question regarding wearing masks is – how much mask-wearing actually happened?

The answer: very little.
🧵/4

A tiny study by Barasheed masked pilgrims attending the Hajj, randomized by tent.  There was no difference in lab-confirmed influenza (only 6 cases in the entire study), but ILI was reduced in the tents with mask wearing in a dose-response relationship in mask-wearing tents:
🧵/3 https://t.co/15Q0AIX3Zj

First of all, seven of these studies evaluate within-household spread.  Diverse results, including some with nearly no secondary attack, while others as high as 20%.

Regardless, mask effectiveness in prolonged cohabitation with a positive case is clearly not generalizable.
🧵/2 https://t.co/HhYRu5DCeC
